Don \"Wardaddy\" Collier.Action: Kills a German lieutenant in a brutal, efficient manner to protect himself.
Ambushes a German lieutenant by hiding behind cover, acts swiftly and lethally with a knife kill, then cleans the blade and remains alert scanning the area.
Looks at the horse eye to eye, gently rubs its muzzle and kisses it, showing care and connection before taking its bridle and saddle
Cuts the map case and Knight’s Cross medal from a dead German soldier despite exhaustion, showing resourcefulness and focus.
Handles a frightened war horse with gentleness and expertise, demonstrating knowledge and control.
Manages to remove bridle, bit, and saddle from the horse skillfully, indicating thorough practical skills.
Climbs aboard and commands the tank 'FURY' confidently despite cramped and filthy conditions, implying leadership and experienced familiarity.
Tosses the Knight’s Cross to Bible to hang among other German decorations, jokes about canned bacon as reward.
Lights a cigarette, scratches a notch in his knife, shows calm routine in danger.
Becomes outraged when Coon-Ass mocks shooting horses, responds with physical violence kicking Coon-Ass.
Calls Coon-Ass an animal and dog, says he only understands fist and boot.

Confidently confirms he shot the enemy ('I knocked him off'), asserts control over his team, distributes enemy weapons and decorations to maintain morale, and remains aware of the dangers lurking despite routine conditions.
Physically assaults a subordinate (Coon-Ass) impulsively over a comment about shooting horses, indicating possible loss of self-control or poor leadership in managing team tensions.
Thanks Bible for warming coffee and accepts it politely.
Reprimands Gordo sharply and uses dismissive language towards him.
Expresses pragmatic acceptance of Red's death without blaming himself harshly.
Shows leadership by calmly studying maps and planning route back, involving the crew.
Dismisses use of Spanish and enforces American identity rigidly among crew.
Uses his knowledge of German as a tactical tool, studies enemy maps to find safe routes, displays leadership by making navigation decisions confidently, listens carefully with finely tuned instincts.
Engages in verbal sparring with crew members but maintains authority and control.
Uses nicknames like 'sweetheart' and casual banter with crew members (e.g., 'Coon-Ass? Anytime, sweetheart.')
Encourages crew calmly during artillery barrage, maintains leadership under pressure ('Move out!', 'Forward! Pick it up!')
Does not show overt emotional support or direct expression of care during stressful moments; communication remains terse and businesslike
Commands Gordo decisively to drive the tank out of danger, calmly scanning for threats with a cold hard stare.
Directs Gordo to drive the tank skillfully out of danger, demonstrating situational awareness and command under fire.
Opens his hatch and exposes himself after the immediate threat has passed, confidently maintaining vigilance.
Insists medics take care of Red's corpse despite their reluctance, threatens them if they don't.
Corrects Lieutenant Parker on Red's name, showing respect for his fallen comrade.
Displays menace and threatens medics to honor the dead, using intimidation rather than appeal.
Responds curtly and grimly to Lieutenant Parker's questions about the battle and casualties.
Drives the Fury tank deftly, spins and parks perfectly alongside newer tanks, demonstrating skillful tank handling.
Hauls Red’s corpse out of the tank and insists medics take care of him, threatening them when they hesitate, showing authoritative and confident leadership.
Explains the situation clearly to Lieutenant Parker, asserting control and knowledge about the battle despite losses.
Acknowledges the failure caused by an inexperienced officer ('Another goddamned green Lieutenant happened'), showing awareness and critical evaluation of the situation.

Responds with a sarcastic, somewhat negative attitude ('A goddamned flank guard mission?') toward his new assignment, which could be seen as a slight lack of enthusiasm or acceptance but maintains composure.
Reassures Norman about combat danger, offers practical advice to new crew member.
Tells crew not to worry about the new Lieutenant, asserts his own authority.
Responds tersely to Norman's introduction with 'Maybe. What the fuck are you?'
Acknowledges the poor condition of his tank and crew with frustration and exhaustion.
Addresses Bible and Coon-Ass respectfully, giving direct orders to restock and fix issues.
Absent from this interaction where tank crew treat Norman roughly; no intervention or defense shown
Leads the tank crew and leaves the new recruit Norman to be assessed by the others, demonstrating confidence in his role and authority.
Does not directly intervene when other crew members intimidate and test Norman, possibly showing trust in the crew's methods but also a non-action in managing group dynamics.
Wardaddy and Gordo tighten track links with wrenches during tank preparation, showing hands-on leadership and practical skill.
Does not intervene or comment on Norman's visible discomfort and fear when cleaning the machine gun and handling personal items of a fallen crewman.
Kills a prisoner of war, justifying it by identifying him as an SS and emphasizing their cruelty.
Accepts command responsibilities and interacts with other soldiers with straightforwardness and some camaraderie.
Pushes Norman to participate in killing, preparing him for harsh realities of war.
Kills a prisoner of war who is an SS soldier, showing harsh but clear moral justification based on enemy type.
Confidently takes command as acting Platoon Sergeant and integrates into the unit quickly.
Questions Lieutenant Parker about mission specifics, requesting to see the overlay to better understand the operation.
Engages in gritty, practical behaviors like marking kills on his knife, displaying a hardened but focused mentality.
Responds to comments or digs from others (e.g., shaving jab) without losing composure.
Recognizes the corporal’s battle fatigue and acknowledges limits of tolerance.
Shrugs off the corporal’s grenade injury and calmly orders to move out without emotional involvement.
Waves goodbye to the outpost sentry with no apparent personal engagement despite the rude greeting.
Addresses Norman calmly and clearly, ensuring he understands commands to avoid friendly fire.
Maintains a stoic, commanding presence likened to an 'iron centaur, half man half tank,' showing emotional reserve.
Engages in dark humor and bitter banter with Coon-Ass, showing little optimism or encouragement about the war or their survival.
Admits he never planned on surviving the war and acknowledges his lack of a home, displaying honesty and vulnerability.
Uses sarcasm and grim language when talking about death and war debts, indicating emotional distance and hardness.
Spreads his map on the turret and marks their destination, demonstrating situational awareness and navigation skill.
Comments on the nature of the mission realistically, recognizing the importance of support and risks involved.
Expresses resignation about survival, showing acceptance but also emotional burden that could impact decision-making.
Talks about poker and owing others, indicating a fatalistic attitude but also a sign of mental distraction or detachment.
Engages in dark humor and banter with Coon-Ass, maintaining morale despite grim circumstances.
Lines up and orders the destruction of the enemy anti-aircraft gun to protect the unit and complete their mission.
Acknowledges the destruction but shows no visible compassion towards the impact on enemy soldiers or nearby civilians.
Quickly identifies the enemy anti-aircraft gun, commands his crew to target and destroy it with precision under combat conditions.
Acknowledges the mission timetable and does not insist on exploiting the destroyed enemy position despite the opportunity.
Warily monitors refugees for potential threats, orders crew to be ready for immediate lethal action if needed, demonstrating vigilance and decisiveness under uncertain conditions.
Commands surrendering enemy soldiers firmly and effectively in German, securing compliance without unnecessary violence.
Responds promptly and obeys hand signals from Lt. Parker to speed up, showing coordination and situational awareness within the unit.
Engages in crude banter about women and morality with crew, showing a rough distrustful humor rather than warmth.
Calls for stopping the horseplay indicating his desire to maintain order and discipline among men he commands.
Confronted with the sight of dead children hanging from telegraph poles, stares directly at them, showing a serious and emotionally engaged reaction.
Maintains discipline and control over his crew during informal banter and distraction-filled moments, telling them to 'Knock off the horseplay.'
Challenges the crew's cynicism with pointed, rhetorical questions about morality and the enemy, demonstrating leadership and critical thinking.
Engages in dark humor about the enemy to maintain morale, showing situational emotional intelligence.
Says 'Kids. They're just kids.' with sadness when referring to Hitler Youth soldiers.
Kills the Hitler Youth soldiers firing on their tank without hesitation.
Kills the burning bow gunner trapped in the tank to put him out of misery.
Kicks the wounded Hitler Youth and kills him with a rifle while insulting him harshly.
Bangs on Norman's hatch demanding him to open it, intimidating him.
Harshly scolds Norman for hesitating to kill the enemy child, harshly insists on brutal killing rules.
After reprimanding Norman, he walks away leaving Norman guilt-ridden and emotionally destroyed.
Declines being called 'sir' by Infantry Sergeant, preferring a more informal address.
Reports his commander is dead but maintains calm and straightforward communication.
Assumes leadership without hesitation after the death of his superior.
Volunteers to lead the column, confidently assumes command when the previous leader is dead.
Double checks his map before moving out, communicates clearly with driver and others.
Interacts respectfully and realistically with Infantry Sergeant, avoids false formality.
Acknowledges limited tank strength honestly to Captain Waggoner.
Calmly listens to Coon-Ass express his fear and anxiety in the turret.
Does not panic or lose composure amidst tense moments, maintaining leadership presence.
No immediate direct action shown in this excerpt to handle Coon-Ass’s breakdown.
Tells Coon-Ass to stop worrying and encourages him firmly to keep going, trying to stabilize his nerves.
Tells Coon-Ass to not scare the young boy any more and emphasizes the need for the boy's presence.
Acknowledges the traumatic event of the boy's death when pressed but does so tersely.
Refers to the shared sadness in the group and tries to refocus his men with a promise of normal comforts after the mission, conveying care in a tough manner.
Refuses to drink with Coon-Ass despite the suggestion, indicating personal restraint rather than camaraderie.
Calms down a frightened subordinate by recognizing battle jitters as normal and insisting on focus
Interrupts and silences a comrade who is spreading fear and negativity to preserve unit morale and function
Refuses to indulge in drinking with a subordinate, suggesting professional restraint
Smiles at the old leathery sergeant, acknowledging him warmly despite the tension.
Commands the troops firmly and efficiently without added encouragement or camaraderie.
Declines to drink with Coon-Ass, maintaining boundaries rather than friendliness.
Conducts a final inspection of tanks and men, ensuring readiness for battle.
Gives clear, precise orders over radio to coordinate tank formation and tactics.
Calms and motivates troops with confident speech.
Smiles at the old sergeant, showing confidence and esprit de corps.
Shows impatience or frustration by grinding his teeth.
Commands tanks and soldiers assertively and clearly in battle, ensuring coordination and warning to not shoot friendly troops.
Orders troops to get off tanks and take defensive positions, demonstrating clear command and situational awareness.
Commands tanks to move out and button up, showing procedural knowledge and leadership under fire.
Leads recon by fire with machine guns effectively to flush enemy and protect infantry, showing tactical skill.
Corrects SGT. Binkowski to avoid friendly fire, displays clear situational awareness and communication.
Commands the crew decisively in battle, directs fire to suppress enemy machine gun position.
Corrects Sergeant Binkowski's movement to maintain mission focus, insists on following plan.
Shouts intense warnings to prevent friendly fire and protect American soldiers
Is focused on solving tactical problems immediately without visible emotional display
Immediately spots and warns a fellow tank to avoid running over American soldiers, giving clear, urgent commands.
Quickly identifies the source of enemy fire, challenges false assumptions from others, and demands clarity under pressure.
Keeps calm and focused after near-miss from a high velocity enemy round, coordinates tank response effectively.
Commands his crew calmly and decisively during combat, gives clear instructions, and protects his crew by directing movements to maintain safe intervals.
Focuses exclusively on tactical combat decisions without explicit emotional support or encouragement to crew members in this excerpt.

Identifies a threat (machine gun position) quickly and directs his crew to neutralize it effectively by running over the enemy position with the tank, showing tactical awareness and decisive leadership.
Orders ruthless but practical actions such as crushing enemy soldiers to prevent threat recurrence, demonstrating a cold but effective battlefield acumen.
Shows situational control and commands his team dynamically in combat, coordinating the Fury tank and other tanks to mow down enemy foxholes efficiently.
Commands soldiers firmly to turn off intercom to stop crying.
Leads tank crew effectively to cover infantry after clearing enemy foxholes.
Communicates clearly and cooperatively with infantry commanders to coordinate actions.
Acknowledges the Old Sergeant's nod of gratitude after the fight.
Effectively uses the tank's .50 Cal machine gun to neutralize enemy foxholes, coordinating the tank crew's firepower skillfully.
Issues clear, precise tactical commands to multiple tank units and infantry, demonstrating confident battlefield leadership.
Maintains composure and control when the infantry soldiers he rescued do not celebrate, showing realistic leadership under stress.
Turns off Norman's intercom to stop him from crying, using blunt authority to maintain focus among his men.
Promises his crew he will keep them alive and insists Norman get in the tank to help, showing a protective attitude toward his men.
Slaps the German corporal's family pictures out of his hand and yells at him in German, showing harshness toward an enemy.
Intervenes to stop soldiers from shooting the terrified German corporal outright, showing a limit to cruelty and some control over his men.
Frogmarches Norman roughly by the neck, demonstrating a forceful, intimidating behavior.
Calms a potentially chaotic and violent situation by preventing a soldier from killing a terrified POW, showing control and command presence.
Immediately recognizes Norman's inexperience and fear but takes charge to bring him up to task, showing leadership under pressure.
Uses physical force (frogmarching Norman) to assert authority and enforce discipline.
Slaps the POW’s pictures away and speaks harshly in German to silence him, demonstrating tough decisiveness but potentially lacking empathy.
Hands Norman the .45 pistol, empowering and entrusting him with responsibility despite Norman’s fear and inexperience.
Forces Norman to kill a sobbing German prisoner by threatening and coercing him.
Holds back from hitting Norman with a pistol despite anger.
Uses intimidation and psychological pressure to force Norman to kill the enemy soldier, demonstrating control and decisiveness in a combat situation.
Shows awareness that moral hesitation can endanger the mission and responds accordingly.
Nearly hits Norman with the pistol but restrains himself, indicating emotional control and command presence.
Leaves Norman devastated and demoralized rather than offering coaching or support, potentially risking platoon cohesion.
Leaves Norman on his knees in the mud after a traumatic event
Crew members describe him as crazy but solid and loyal, and his leadership keeps the crew together
Norman perceives him as the biggest asshole he ever met
Gordo puts a brotherly arm around Norman to comfort him, indicating a warm crew dynamic likely influenced by Wardaddy
Norman sees Wardaddy as fearless, despite Wardaddy previously panicking in North Africa
Wardaddy smokes alone, possibly feeling guilty about his harsh treatment of Norman
Watches the bombers with admiration and encourages his men with ‘There you go, boys. Keep pounding them.’
Scans the town carefully with binoculars, demonstrates cautious but determined leadership preparing for assault.
Communicates clearly and firmly with the platoon and superiors, focusing on mission objectives without unnecessary harshness.
Uses binoculars to carefully scout the town before assault, assessing the situation with focus.
Communicates clearly and efficiently over the company net, establishing orders and confirming instructions.
Instructs the platoon to proceed cautiously and to 'button up' until the enemy situation is clearer.
Shields his men by taking point on the wedge and coordinating the attack carefully, showing leadership and concern for their safety.
Kills an unarmed old man immediately after a rifle shot, then violently destroys the hotel to flush out enemy soldiers.
Encourages Norman after his first kill, telling him 'Good one, kid. Keep stacking 'em up.', showing support and affirmation.
Encourages Sergeant Binkowski to engage enemy, speaks in a familiar and motivating tone ('You better button up').
Takes careful, precise shot to neutralize disoriented enemy soldier rather than excess violence.
Focuses on tactical advancement and survival under heavy fire with little visible emotional expression or personal connection.
Identifies enemy threats quickly and directs Sergeant Binkowski to neutralize a close and dangerous machine gun position in a cellar, showing tactical awareness and decisiveness.
Returns fire efficiently and eliminates an exposed, disoriented German soldier with a precise shot.
Responds calmly to a near-deadly anti-tank shell impact despite being momentarily stunned and obstructed by dust and debris, maintaining composure under pressure.
Gives clear, calm commands under fire and directs crew effectively during combat.
Orders the destruction of enemy soldiers with no apparent hesitation or mercy.
Identifies and calls out enemy threats quickly and accurately (e.g. 'Antitank! Left! Fox Love!').
Commands the crew efficiently with precise instructions (e.g. 'Phosphorous! Five zero! Fire when ready!').
Ensures thorough destruction of enemy threat by ordering a follow-up high explosive shell after the phosphorous round.
Maintains focus and control in intense combat situations, coordinating between different units and firing effectively.
Allows the surrender of frightened child soldiers, preventing unnecessary bloodshed.
Uses harsh language and orders to shoot the SS officer responsible for hanging children.
Offers his hand to Norman and tries to reassure him after a violent encounter.
Seeks Norman's agreement that killing the enemy is 'nothing,' indicating a desire for shared moral support rather than empathy.
Leads Norman to see the aftermath of Nazi leaders' deaths to likely justify their actions.
Approaches Norman to guide and mentor him after his first kill, attempts to normalize the act of killing to maintain squad cohesion and morale.
Leads Norman to the Nazi Party Headquarters to expose harsh realities and toughen him up emotionally and mentally.
Seeks verbal agreement from Norman to justify killing, showing need for external validation rather than pure confidence.
Shows Norman the dead Nazi men and women to prepare him for harsh realities.
Tells Norman to keep following his orders to survive.
Rushes to investigate a suspicious face in a building, taking lead and protecting his men.
Forces entry into a woman's apartment despite her protest, showing little tolerance or kindness to civilians.
Commands a hidden woman to come out immediately, showing control over the situation for security.
Drags Emma from the bedroom and locks the door, showing control and possible harshness.
Pushes Emma onto the couch, then sits down looking very tired and serious.
Offers Emma rare food items (eggs, coffee, bacon) and cigarettes, showing generosity and care.
Tells Norman to put the gun away and sit down, trying to ease tension and nervousness.
Forces Norman to lock the door to ensure security, showing command presence and control under tense circumstances.
Confronts Irma about her deception, demonstrating awareness and understanding of potential dangers.
Recognizes the importance of morale by offering rare food and cigarettes to Emma, skillfully using limited resources to build trust and cooperation.
Sits down wearily after securing the situation, displaying a moment of vulnerability but also realistic acknowledgment of fatigue.
Protects Emma and Norman's relationship, giving Norman a chance to act first and showing pride like a big brother.
Responds to Norman’s embarrassment about his burn scars by quickly covering them, avoiding vulnerability.
States to Irma in German that 'They're young. And they’re alive.' showing understanding and acceptance of youth and life despite harsh conditions.
Not interested in Irma despite her apparent interest, politely disengages without rudeness.
Wardaddy sits quietly with Norman, signaling understanding without requiring Norman to speak.
Wardaddy drinks coffee silently, showing restraint and composure after Norman's intimate moment.
Warns his men not to touch Emma and threatens violence if they do.
Gently takes the photograph from Coon-Ass and respectfully returns it to Irma, expressing condolences in German.
Allows Coon-Ass’s crude comment and insult without direct retaliation.
Controls a tense situation with drunk men by calmly asserting boundaries and defusing potential conflict.
Handles the photograph incident with tact and respect, communicating in German and showing empathy to Irma.
Calmly manages safety by ordering Norman away from the window to avoid danger from drunk soldiers outside.
Politely refuses alcohol in German by pushing away the glass without causing offense.
Threatens Coon-Ass into silence, asserting control to stop defeatist talk.
Smiles warmly at Norman and engages him with friendly, personal questions about his mother’s cooking.
Pulls his .45 and slams it on the table to silence Coon-Ass, asserting control with confidence and decisiveness.
Maintains calm and focus by eating his meal while others are tense, showing composure under pressure.
Responds warmly to Norman with small talk, creating trust and maintaining morale among his men.
Reads and accepts the mission promptly and prepares to move out efficiently.
Reassures the Company Messenger to ensure the women are treated well by the boys.
Admits openly to not knowing what will happen to the women.
Focuses on military orders and mission without showing warmth explicitly in interactions with others during tense moments.
Responds to Captain Waggoner's intel with relevant questions and makes notes before agreeing to the mission promptly.
Instructs the Company Messenger to ensure the women are not mistreated, showing awareness of unit discipline beyond combat.
Admits to Irma that he doesn't know what will happen next, showing honesty but also uncertainty.
Does a quick check of the Fury’s tracks before battle, showing responsibility for the crew’s safety.
Non-action: Does not intervene in Norman’s breakdown or Coon-Ass's harsh treatment of Norman.
Does a quick check of the Fury’s tracks before moving out.
Shakes the Captain's hand and thanks him before the Captain is killed by a sniper.
Immediately orders to move out and commands his unit with urgency to counter the sniper threat.
Shows concern for Norman by radioing his crew to be alert and protect each other from danger.
Commands destruction of a village to flush out the sniper, resulting in widespread devastation.
Immediately orders an aggressive counterattack against the sniper after the Captain is shot, showing quick situational awareness and decisiveness.
Uses periscope effectively to assess damage and tactical situation, then commands cessation of fire based on evaluation.
Leads the tanks out after ineffective fire, recognizing when to disengage to preserve forces.
Thanks the Captain calmly before he is shot, maintaining professionalism and composure under pressure.
Invites Norman to join him atop the tank and operate the machine gun, trying to include him and share responsibility.
Acknowledges Norman's feelings and attempts to empathize by sharing his own long experience in the war.
Dismisses Norman’s protest ‘You have no idea how I feel,’ by stating 'I know how you feel,' potentially minimizing Norman’s emotions.
Describes the harsh realities of war bluntly and matter-of-factly without sugarcoating, emphasizing the ongoing suffering and killing.
States he has no problem killing his own kin because of war’s demands, showing a tough, pragmatic, and possibly emotionally detached stance.

Demonstrates deep self-awareness and responsibility by openly recounting a personal tragedy that resulted from his own reckless behavior; accepts the consequences of his past mistakes and acknowledges harsh lessons learned.
Displays emotional control and pragmatic acceptance of suffering by reflecting on the harsh realities of his past rather than denying or blaming others.
Prioritizes sharing his difficult history to communicate a meaningful lesson despite the emotional weight, showing leadership and purpose in his communication with Norman.
Engages in reckless and intoxicated behavior that leads to a tragic accident harming his family, demonstrating poor judgment before the war.
Acknowledges a lack of competence in his youth related to alcohol abuse and impulsive decisions which had catastrophic personal consequences.
Keeps Norman's secret about his past and inner feelings.
Explains to Norman that concentration camp victims are regular people, showing empathy and awareness.
Fires assault rifle into the air to scare civilians, causing them to drop tools and run.
Keeps sensitive information about his past and the war to himself, maintaining secrecy among his men.
Displays knowledge and awareness about the war, the enemy, and the atrocities they encounter (e.g., concentration camp victims).
Uses his assault rifle to fire in the air causing civilians to scatter, demonstrating control and confidence in influencing the environment.
Engages in a somewhat casual or mocking interaction (laughing after firing into the air), which may undermine seriousness or strategic discretion.
Stops with Sgt. Davis to carefully study the battlefield and calmly plans defensive positions to protect the crossroads, emphasizing caution and preparation.
Quickly orders the tanks to reverse and take cover after the sudden Tiger tank attack, staying composed and directing his team to safety.
Refuses to retreat in face of a superior enemy tank, insists on attacking the Tiger tank to protect his men and complete the mission.
Recognizes the threat of the Tiger tank and immediately coordinates his crew to engage it despite being outgunned.
Rejects retreat and chooses an aggressive tactic (fast right turn and direct attack) to outmaneuver and attack the Tiger tank.
Commands precise battlefield maneuvers and uses team coordination under deadly threat.
Commands his crew to blind and attack the enemy tank aggressively to protect his men and accomplish the mission.
Swears at the enemy, calling them 'animals', showing disdain but also concern for his men’s safety.
Commands his crew to load white phosphorous rounds to blind the enemy tank and directs fire carefully at weak points of the Tiger tank, adjusting strategy on the fly.
Gives clear, precise, confident orders under heavy fire, demonstrating awareness of battlefield tactics and quick decision-making.
Attempts to shoot the Tiger tank himself but misses the first shot; however, quickly recovers and directs a successful attack.
Asks Norman how it felt to kill, encouraging his confidence.
Acknowledges the deaths of comrades calmly without emotional outburst.
Tells Sgt. Davis to shake off fear, showing expectation of resilience rather than consolation.
Maintains focus on mission despite losses, demonstrates pragmatic leadership rather than emotional support.
Maintains composure after heavy losses and encourages Sgt. Davis to shake off fear and continue the mission.
Uses binoculars to scan the area and assess threat level before giving orders.
Fails to detect hidden Tiger tank in the barn, resulting in an ambush on Sgt. Davis' tank.
Urgently commands and encourages crew under fire without panic
Calls Gordo 'dumbass' during tense moment
Calmly directs the crew during a tense tank battle, communicates clear instructions to Gordo and Bible
Puts an arm around Bible and says 'Good shooting.' after a tense battle moment.
Maintains steady leadership and control during tense tank battle, showing calm and encouragement.
Focuses on tactical command and survival, with minimal expressed emotion beyond brief encouragement.
Lets Gordo vent and passes him a bottle of brandy.
Smiles at Norman reassuringly, knowing he will be okay.
Replies sarcastically to Coon-Ass about the dead platoon, showing callousness.
Encourages the men to carry on with their duties despite the hardship.
Lets men vent their frustrations, offers brandy to Gordo to calm him, acknowledges Norman's mental state, and calmly redirects focus to the mission with a mix of humor and determination.
Responds sarcastically to Coon-Ass's doubt about being the last tank and reassures the crew with dry humor, maintaining morale despite overwhelming odds.
Does not engage emotionally with complaints, appears callous as noted by Bible, which could undermine empathy but maintains focus on mission.
Calms the crew after mine explosion, reassures Norman by explaining mines won't harm him and personally covers him while he inspects buildings.
Commands Norman to exit the tank despite Norman’s fear, pushing him into a dangerous situation.
Casually jokes about shooting to get a drink despite tense situation.
Assigns Norman to keep watch, giving him clear orders.
Orders to keep going despite danger and mines; assigns Norman to sentry duty after probing for mines.
Responds to Coon-Ass warning about mines with readiness to take a risk, indicating confident leadership.
Demonstrates situational awareness and directs team effectively in a hazardous environment.
Greets Norman teasingly but listens seriously to his warning and acts to protect him and the group.
Dismisses Norman’s concern initially as bums looking for someone to surrender to.
Physically pulls Norman out of danger upon seeing approaching German soldiers.

Remains alert and armed as sentry, responds calmly to Norman's warning about approaching German soldiers, investigates the threat personally, and ensures others keep working while he checks the situation.
Initially downplays Norman's warning by assuming the approaching Germans are just 'bums looking for someone to surrender to,' potentially underestimating the threat.
Refuses to run from superior enemy forces, choosing to hold the crossroads with his men despite near-certain death.
Motivates and leads his men through bravery and a grim but humorous smile.
Uses dark humor when discussing killing the enemy and roasting them, fostering camaraderie.
Shows trust in Norman and the men by assigning duties and expecting their cooperation.
Decides to hold the crossroads against overwhelming SS forces rather than retreat, demonstrating resolve and leadership in dire circumstances.
Organizes the men to play dead to deceive the enemy before launching a counterattack, showing tactical thinking and battlefield savvy.
Checks his weapon and personally prepares materials to execute the ambush, indicating thoroughness and hands-on leadership.
Puts his own jacket on a corpse to cover it respectfully before burning it.
Helps carry a body and prepares to burn it as a tactical decision.
Directs men efficiently and firmly, using strong language but clear commands.

Organizes crew to prepare the tank efficiently, including assigning tasks, supervising ammunition loading, and setting up defensive measures like burning enemy packs and staging the corpse as a distraction.
Demonstrates tactical deception by disguising battlefield conditions (e.g., burning enemy supplies and corpse to appear as a broken tank), showing situational awareness.
Responds quickly and confidently to aid in handling a fallen comrade and directs the crew with commands.

Does not explain technical terms until asked (e.g., waits for Norman to ask about 'cannister' before explaining), showing some awareness of crew knowledge gaps but potentially limited proactive instruction.
Shares French Cognac with the crew and offers it to Bible, fostering camaraderie and easing tension.
Knowingly quotes Bible scripture to connect with Bible, showing attentiveness and respect.
Nicknames Norman 'Machine', welcoming him into the crew and boosting morale.
Recalls correctly the Bible verse and chapter when Bible mentions it, demonstrating knowledge and attentiveness.
Initiates shared drinking to bond the crew and ease tension before battle, showing situational awareness and leadership skill.
Drinks alcohol despite the stressful situation and imminent combat, which could risk impairment.
Nicknames Norman 'Machine' to boost morale and integrate him into the crew, effectively reinforcing group cohesion.
Deliberately waits to give the order to fire until the target is vulnerable, maintaining control under pressure.
Uses strict command ('Nobody does nothing until I say...') to maintain order and protect his crew.
Commands tank crew to aggressively attack enemies without hesitation, showing focus on mission rather than crew emotional needs.

Strategically directs his crew to fire effectively, coordinates machine gun fire with precision adjustments, uses grenades tactically against enemy troops, and continuously monitors the surroundings via periscope.
Keeps composure and command in utter chaos, giving clear, confident, and timely orders that enhance the tank crew's effectiveness.
Yanks out broken periscope, quickly replaces it and continues observing to protect crew
Comments 'It’s a fucking turkey shoot' amid battle, showing detached, brutal attitude
Takes swig from bottle and lights cigarette under fire, indicating stress but no outward comfort offered to crew
Stops firing and instructs crew to cease fire if no targets are visible to conserve ammo.
Responds quickly to protect crew from enemy threat by directing turret movement and staying alert for danger.
Quickly troubleshoots and replaces the overheated coax machine gun under combat conditions, ensuring continued firepower.
Commands the crew to cease fire to conserve ammo when no targets are visible, demonstrating tactical resourcefulness.
Maintains situational awareness by using the periscope to detect enemy movement and quickly directs the turret to evade an incoming rocket.
Calmly puts out fire inside the tank despite horrors, keeps crew focused after a comrade dies.
Tells Bible 'He’s gone. We gotta fight.' showing pragmatic but unsentimental approach to death.
Shares ammo with Bible and takes initiative to get more smoke grenades to protect the crew.
Quickly puts out the fire inside the tank after the rocket hit, preventing it from spreading and endangering the crew further.
Immediately assesses that the 75 mm cannon is damaged and orders Bible to stay on the coaxial machine gun, adapting to the damaged weaponry effectively.
Maintains calm and control under pressure, scanning the area with the periscope to identify threats despite the stressful situation.
Recognizes ammunition shortage and takes initiative by asking for ammo and preparing smoke grenades to provide cover for gathering more supplies, showing tactical awareness.
Directs his crew clearly and leads aggressively from the front during battle, throwing smoke grenades and distributing ammo to keep everyone supplied.
Bangs on Bible’s shoulder and shouts in his ear during intense combat, demonstrating team communication and concern for effectiveness.
Exposes himself to danger by climbing out of the tank hatch under fire, showing willingness to share risk with his men.
Tells Bible it's alright after stabbing the SS trooper and asks for help.
Shrugs off his own injury and points out Bible is also hit.
Pulls knife and kills a soldier who attacked him without hesitation.
Orders crew efficiently under fire, manages limited ammo inventory, maintains calm in intense combat.
Fights and kills an enemy soldier in close quarters despite sustaining a facial injury.
Shrugs off his own bullet wound, maintaining focus on the battle and crew.
Allows Bible to treat his gunshot wound despite the pain, showing trust and reliance on his crew.
Maintains focus and organizes crew under pressure despite his own injury, demonstrating responsibility and care.
Uses rough language ('Don’t shit your panties') to keep morale, mixing harshness with encouragement under stress.
Organizes the crew under fire despite being injured, patches his own wound with Bible's help, quickly assesses their limited ammunition and plans for continued defense calmly.
Encourages the crew not to panic and takes initiative by climbing out of the tank to manage ammunition under dangerous conditions.
Fights fiercely alongside comrades, calling for ammo and continuing to protect team under heavy fire.
Uses harsh language against enemy soldiers, mocking and mocking their threats.
Shows readiness to defend and support teammates under intense combat conditions.
Pulls a pin on a grenade and throws it accurately into enemy forces despite dense smoke, causing casualties and disrupting enemy attack.
Commands readiness and fires back rapidly and blindly into the smoke after enemy attack begins.
Runs out of ammo amid heavy fire and delegates resupply to Bible promptly.
Continues fighting despite being hit twice by bullets.
No hesitation in using enemy weapons and aggressive verbal insults in German to intimidate enemy forces.
Gently wipes blood from Bible's face and apologizes sincerely.
Admits to being scared to Norman, shares vulnerability.
Offers Norman bottle of Cognac despite wounds and danger.
Pleads with Norman not to surrender to protect him from harm.
Kills without hesitation to protect himself and Norman, showing ruthless violence.
Looks at Norman to urge him to escape amidst life-threatening danger.
Dies heroically defending the tank, enabling Norman a chance to survive.
Leads the tank crew effectively in battle to the point where enemies are closing in and deploying grenades, signifying competent command and combat skill.
Dies when grenades explode inside the tank, which implies failure in protecting himself and the crew, but given the context of intense combat this may not be a strong indicator of incompetence.
Norman covers Wardaddy’s body with his jacket and gently crosses his arms over his chest; Wardaddy’s hand is big and calloused, with marked personal notches on his knife.
Wardaddy sits silently in the turret after being mortally wounded, showing no outward emotional expression or communication.
Although gravely wounded and near death, maintains a presence that inspires loyalty and respect, as Norman honors him by covering his body and handling his belongings with care.
No direct action in this excerpt since he is incapacitated, showing his inability to act or lead at this point.
